SENT.plain: Inflammatory damage and oxidative stress play an important role in cerebral ischemic pathogenesis and may represent a target for treatment
Baicalein, isolated from the traditional Chinese herbal medicine Huangqin, is an antioxidant and anti-inflammatory agent on one hand and a lipoxygenase inhibitor on the other hand
However, little is known regarding the mechanism of baicalein's neuroprotection in ischemic stroke
We therefore investigated the potential neuroprotective effects of baicalein and explored the underlying mechanisms
Male, Sprague-Dawley rats were subjected to permanent middle cerebral artery occlusion (MCAO) and baicalein was administered intravenously immediately after cerebral ischemia
At 24h after MCAO neurological deficit, brain water content and infarct sizes were measured

Immunohistochemistry, western blot and reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) were used to analyse the expression of 12/15-lipoxygenase (12/15-LOX), p38 mitogen-activated protein kinase (p38 MAPK) and cytosolic phospholipase A2 (cPLA2) at gene and protein levels in ischemic brain cortex

The results showed that baicalein improved neurological deficit, reduced brain water content and infarct sizes, and downregulated the overexpression of 12/15-LOX, p38 MAPK and cPLA2 typically seen with MCAO
The results indicated that baicalein protected the brain from damage caused by MCAO, and this effect may be through downregulation of 12/15-LOX, p38 MAPK and cPLA2 expression
